devhub-2023-rebranding-and-transforming-:
As we reflect on the transformative journey of 2023, we are reminded of a year marked by dynamic shifts and growth within the NEAR Developer ecosystem. From the rapid evolution of Open Web technology to the surge in developer engagement, the past year has been nothing short of remarkable for DevHub.


At the onset of 2023, DevHub set out on a mission to redefine what developer engagement truly means. From hosting hackathons in multiple regions to fostering collaborative partnerships, our commitment to empowering developers has remained unwavering. Read all about our highlights and success from the previous year below! 

## **📚Empowering the Next Generation of Open Web Developers with NEAR Campus**

One of the pivotal milestones of 2023 was the launch of NEAR Campus (in October 2023), our initiative aimed at engaging junior software engineers early on as they choose their career path. We’ve been at top schools like University of Oxford and Cambridge. 

![Alt Text](https://i.ibb.co/hsGSVSm/NEAR-CAMPUS.png)


With the establishment of university clubs across diverse regions and continents, including Latin America, Asia, Turkey, and Africa, we have successfully cultivated a vibrant ecosystem of more than 100 students. In 2024 we expect to have access to 500 junior developers. 

Not only do we engage students, but we also engage with faculty. By providing access to cutting-edge tools and resources, our goal is to integrate NEAR into the standard toolkit for developers in learning institutions.
 
## **🌎 Decentralizing Developer Relations**

In Q4, we embarked on a significant revamp of our Developer Relations strategy. Our aim was to make it more accessible and engaging for developers. We achieved this by introducing additional office hours and hosting regular workshops via Twitter Spaces, which led to a notable increase in developer engagement. We also established a consistent presence at hackathons and in-person events. Collaborating closely with the marketing team, we launched challenges and bounty boosters to incentivize participation during these events. 

We also adopted a decentralized approach to DevRel, onboarding team members in locations where hackathons are held rather than having team members travel extensively. This decentralization strategy has led to improvements in tooling, infrastructure, and documentation. Our initial focus has been on the launch of China DevRels, with plans to expand into other regions such as Korea, Brazil, and Asia…where English is not the primary language.

 
## **🏆 Hackathon Innovation with Hackbox**


In 2023 we productized everything we know about Hackathons, bounties and judging submissions…by developing “Hackbox” , a launchpad designed to streamline the hosting of hackathons , guiding first time hosts through setting up , marketing and hosting their own NEAR Hackathon. In collaboration with our vibrant community, we have successfully hosted 4 Hackbox hackathons across different regions, exposing 4,000 individuals to NEAR technology. With over 200 submissions and a keen focus on post-hackathon engagement, we monitor developer activities after every hackathon using “shard-dog” to track GitHub commits and we make sure Developers know what to do in the NEAR ecosystem after they join. 
 
## **🛠 Tooling and Infrastructure**

Significant progress has been made in enhancing the developer experience, leveraging two robust ecosystems: Rust and JavaScript. In the Rust stack, we're actively developing tools to streamline onboarding processes, including an online IDE that sets up your environment in just 5 minutes.

This online IDE integrates essential tooling such as `Cargo Near`, `NEAR CLI`, `NEAR Workspaces`, and `NEAR SDK`. While many find our tools intuitive, we're continuously seeking areas for improvement.

Transitioning to the JavaScript stack, we're focused on developing smart contracts using `NEAR SDK JS`. Additionally, our partnerships are facilitating the creation of an interactive education platform for learning `NEAR SDK JS` …so watch out for that!

Jutsu, another exciting project in our ecosystem, is seamlessly integrated into Hackbox for an enhanced hackathon experience. Through these tools, we've witnessed individuals familiarize themselves with the technology and deploy applications in less than an hour. They find these tools remarkably user-friendly and conducive to development.
 
## **The DevHub Portal**

A year ago, we launched the DevHub Portal!  designed to cater to every aspect of a developer's journey within the NEAR ecosystem. Serving as a one-stop shop, it offers a plethora of resources essential for making an impact on NEAR. 


![Alt Text](https://i.ibb.co/7jRMw8y/Dev-Hub-Portal.png)

Here, developers can share ideas and proposals, seek sponsorship, discover communities, and engage with like-minded individuals on a variety of different topics.

The development of this portal has been a collaborative effort, with numerous contributors involved in its iterative process. Together, we've implemented features such as community spaces, GitHub integrations, and announcements. Since its inception, the portal has garnered significant engagement, with over 400 unique authors contributing more than 2,000 long-form posts spanning from insightful ideas to detailed solutions.

Moreover, we've provided sponsorship to over 400 projects and individuals, while also overseeing major project transitions such as MyNearWallet and NEAR Blocks. 

Looking ahead, we have several exciting features in the pipeline, including a redesign of the proposal journey and the transformation of the portal into a tool accessible not only to DevHub but also to any other partner within the ecosystem!
 
## 👨🏼‍⚖️Technical Governance

In our commitment to shaping NEAR's development, we introduced NEAR Enhancement Proposals ([NEPs](https://github.com/near/NEPs/blob/master/neps/nep-0001.md)) . As a way to allow anyone submit proposals, for protocol upgrades, contract standard enhancements, and more. To ensure the credibility and progress of these proposals, we established over 6 formal Working Groups (WGs) comprising of subject matter experts who review and make decisions. Collaborating closely with the community, we have approved over 35 NEPs and discussed more than 75 across various aspects of the tech stack.

Each day, we strive to refine our governance process further. You can revisit the decision-making process through recorded sessions on YouTube or explore the complete history of NEPs on GitHub. Additionally, we've launched numerous community groups, hosting over 35 brainstorming sessions to generate new ideas and solutions, some of which have resulted in the creation of new NEPs.

We encourage anyone with ideas to propose them and actively participate in our community or start their own! 
 
## Fellowship Program

Through our fellowship program, we welcomed contributors who have made a significant impact. This initiative resulted in over 1000 commits that contributed to pull requests and the maintenance of more than 20 projects, including CLI SDKs and their dependencies. We're currently polishing the NEAR SDK Rust in preparation for its 5.0 release, thanks to the dedication of our valued contributors who have played a crucial role in our journey.
 
## Upcoming Initiatives in 2024

Looking ahead of 2024, we have some exciting surprises in store:

1. **Awareness and Engagement:**
    - We'll be ramping up our efforts to provide more developer-focused content, including blog articles, podcasts, and Twitter Spaces sessions. Additionally, we're opening up these opportunities to the community, inviting everyone to participate in the conversation. Join us at ETH Denver to be a part of it!
    - We've already launched ongoing challenges, allowing developers to hack on NEAR each month, earn bounties, and gain exclusive access to future hackathons and events.
2. **NEAR Campus:**
    - We're launching quarterly cohorts for NEAR Campus, inviting universities and blockchain clubs to join. It's an open application process, and we're actively seeking the best blockchain clubs to onboard. Research grants will also be available.
3. **Events:**
    - We're gearing up for four cohorts of Hackbox hackathons and meetups. Additionally, we'll host “Hackbox meets” for those not ready for full-scale hackathons but interested in smaller-scale NEAR meetups. This year, we're supporting five ETH Global hackathons, starting with ETHLondon in March. We're also introducing a NEAR-native hackathon platform.
4. **DevDAO Operations:**
    - We're set to relaunch the portal, streamlining payments for our trustees to expedite the process for our contributors. We'll also be scaling partnerships within our organization's ecosystem.
5. **Tooling:**
    - Expect top-notch developer experience with enhanced tools for BOS components and other elements of the ecosystem. We're working on out-of-the-box solutions, including AI, zk-SNARKs, multi-chain tools, chain abstraction, and more.
6. **Regional DevRel Teams:**
    - We'll be launching regional Developer Relations teams in LATAM and Asia, nurturing regional certified developer programs, and fostering developer incentive programs.

As we look forward to the exciting year ahead, we invite you to join us on this transformative journey. Together we’ll strengthen the DevHub platform and build a hub where decentralized development knows no bounds.

## Get Involved 🤩

1. **NEAR Campus:** Join us in empowering the next generation of developers through [NEAR Campus](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=near-campus&tab=about-us).
2. **Host a Hackathon / Meetup:** Explore the possibilities of [Hackbox](https://near.org/hackbox.near/widget/home) and host your own NEAR meetup.
3. **Contribute:** Share your ideas and proposals on the [DevHub Portal](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=feed) and become a part of our vibrant community of innovators.

near-bounty-booster-program-3021:
Calling all devs!  Get ready to take your hackathon projects to the next level with **NEAR Bounty Booster**! If you participate in any hackathon and choose to build on NEAR, you'll have the chance to earn some serious cash! We'll boost your prize with an extra bounty, giving you the support you need to keep building!


  
#### How It Works 🤩 :

**To be eligible for the Bounty Booster,** you must participate in any hackathon we are not sponsoring and submit a project utilizing the NEAR stack. If you win, you can claim the additional bounties the program offers. Any developer anywhere in the world can benefit from the support and resources provided by NEAR DevHub if they choose to build on the NEAR ecosystem.

The Bounty Booster program is designed to reward your hard work and innovation. We will match the entire prize money won by participants who use the NEAR stack in any hackathon up to a maximum of $5,000. The exact percentage matched is determined by the NEAR DevHub team on a case-by-case basis, ensuring the program can adapt to the unique circumstances of each project and developer. For example, if your team wins a $2,000 prize at a hackathon, NEAR will boost your winnings with an additional $2000!!!

Participating in the Bounty Booster is straightforward. After submitting a project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, Developers must fill out the following [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) and tweet about their submission using specific hashtags, tagging the relevant hackathon and @NEARDevHub. You can see a sample tweet [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z).

Please review our Terms & Conditions for more information about the NEAR Bounty Booster program, including eligibility requirements, application process, and payment details. If you have further questions or need assistance, please contact us at boris@neardevhub.org.
  
## Terms & Conditions
----
  
#### Eligibility 👨‍💻:  

To qualify for the Bounty Booster, 

- The hacker team must submit a project using any part of the NEAR stack to a hackathon not sponsored by NEAR and win a prize. 

- To be considered to have "won" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers.

`NOTE` The "NEAR stack" refers to the suite of technologies and tools provided by NEAR, including Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools.

  
#### Application Process ✍️: 

- Upon submitting their project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, the hacker team must post a tweet announcing their submission.

- The tweet must include the following: A mention of the hackathon they are participating in The @NEARDevHub handle
The hashtags:` #NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR`.

- A sample tweet can be seen [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z). 

- The hacker team must complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link), providing all required information and links to their winning project.

- Teams can submit multiple Bounty Booster applications for projects they have submitted to non-NEAR-sponsored hackathons. Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.

  
#### Bounty Matching 🤝: 

- The NEAR Bounty Booster program will match a portion of the bounty the eligible hacker team won in a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon.

- The maximum amount the program matches is $5,000 per team.

- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.

  
#### Verification and Payment ✅: 

- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.

- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.

- Verification and payment will be subject to NF's policies and T&Cs

- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.

  

Learn more about NEAR by checking out our 👉 [docs](https://docs.near.org/)
##### Happy Building!


![img](https://tracker.metricool.com/c3po.jpg?hash=6d58941e45233e13812f44fb26c74949)

running-an-rpc-node-3022:
**In recent news, NEAR announced a partncership with LAVA network to scale the RPC service providers by incentivising node operators. Let's take this opportunity to talk about what these RPC nodes are and how to run one ourselves.***

## What is an RPC node?
An RPC (Remote Procedure Call) node is a system that connects the blockchain with the outside world. This way, users and applications can request information from the blockchain through these RPC nodes and send transactions to be processed.

#### Why would we want to run an RPC node?
One would want to run their own RPC node for multiple reasons. One reason might be having a dedicated RPC for your users and applications so you do not need to rely on public RPCs that might get congested. Another reason is to contribute your node to a private RPC endpoint to help it scale, thus improving the throughput of the network services.

#### Before we start
This article will follow the official node docs, focusing on setting up a basic node for testnet.

`warning: This article will not dwell on server security (e.g., setting up firewalls, rate limiters, etc). We encourage you to read more about hardening (securing) your server and its services.`

#### The Hardware
The recommended hardware section on the node docs lists the following config:

Hardware
Recommended Specifications
CPU
8-Core (16-Thread) Intel i7/Xeon or equivalent with AVX support|
CPU Features
CMPXCHG16B, POPCNT, SSE4.1, SSE4.2, AVX
RAM
20GB DDR4
Storage
1TB NVMe SSD



RPC nodes store the last five epochs of data, requiring a large amount of storage to accommodate this. However, this amount may vary due to network activity and protocol upgrades, so it's always better to exceed the recommendations a bit.

If we don't have a machine with such specifications, we can choose a server provider such as Azure, AWS, Google Cloud, Hetzner, or OVH, just to name a few.

#### Setting up
After spinning up our server, we can begin setting up our node.

	info
	Since it is a popular distribution, we will use `Ubuntu 22.04`, so your actual command lines may vary.

The following lines will install the necessary packages needed by nearcore and some tools that we will need later.

```bash
# Update system and install relevant apps
$ sudo apt update
$ sudo apt install -y git binutils-dev libcurl4-openssl-dev zlib1g-dev libdw-dev libiberty-dev cmake gcc g++ python-is-python3 docker.io protobuf-compiler libssl-dev pkg-config clang llvm cargo awscli httpie

# Install Rust
$ curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh -s -- -y
$ source "$HOME/.cargo/env"
```

#### Getting and Compiling nearcore
When writing the latest `nearcore` release is `1.37.0`, make sure to check the latest version on the GitHub repo.

Let's clone the repository, compile the code, and move the resulting binary into `/usr/local/bin`

```
$ git clone https://github.com/near/nearcore
$ cd nearcore
$ git fetch origin --tags
$ git checkout tags/1.36.5 -b my_rpc_node
$ make release
$ sudo mv /nearcore/target/release/neard /usr/local/bin/neard
```

#### Initialize a working directory
To run an RPC node we need to initialize a working directory, obtaining the genesis configuration of the blockchain.

```
$ neard init --chain-id testnet --download-genesis
$ wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/build.nearprotocol.com/nearcore-deploy/testnet/config.json -P ~/.near/
```

`warning
We recommend you run this command with a designated [service account](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/314725/what-is-the-difference-between-user-and-service-account). Do not run it as the `root` user.`

#### Replacing the default configuration
Let's remove the default configuration and get the pre-populated one provided by NEAR.
Syncing with the last backup
As a final step before running the node, we must first sync up with the network. This means our node needs to download all the headers and blocks that other nodes in the network already have.

Backups are frequently updated, so we need to determine which one is the latest before syncing the data from it.

```
$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp s3://near-protocol public/backups/testnet/rpc/latest .
$ LATEST=$(cat latest)
$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp --no-sign-request --recursive s3://near-protocol-public/backups/testnet/rpc/$LATEST ~/.near/data
```

`info`: This will take a while, so you might want to make use of [screen](https://quickref.me/screen) or [tmux](https://github.com/tmux/tmux/wiki), which we will not be covered in this article

#### Running the node
Start the node by running

```bash
$ neard --home /root/.near run
```

Our node has synced with the last backup available, but since some time has passed, it will need to catch up with the remaining blocks it missed. At this point, it is normal to see messages such as:

`WARN chunks: Error processing partial encoded chunk response: UnknownChunk`
or
`ERROR network: Failed to store connection attempt. peer_info=PeerInfo ....`

After a while, it should have caught up with the network, and the logs output would look similar:



**Congratulations! Our node is running, and we will see the logs output as long as we keep the process alive.**

#### Persisting the process
Explain [todo]
Create a `near.service` file in `/etc/systemd/system/` with the following content:

```
[Unit]
Description=NEAR RPC node
After=network-online.target

[Service]
User=root
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/neard --home /root/.near run
Restart=always
RestartSec=10
LimitNOFILE=65535

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

To make use of our newly created service, we should reload systemctl and enable it

```
$ systemctl daemon-reload
$ systemctl enable near.service
$ systemctl start near
```

Once the process starts, we can use the following command to follow the output logs

```
journalctl --fu near -o cat
```

This time if we hit `[ctrl]+[c]` the logs would be closed, but our node will continue running in the background.
Interact locally

Now that our node is up and running persistently, it is ready to receive http requests via `http://localhost:3030`. To learn more on how to interact with RPC nodes, we can refer to the documentation [found here](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/introduction#near-rpc---quick-links)

Let's get the answer to life, the universe, and everything by calling the function `get_answer` on the smart contract deployed on `the_answer.testnet`.

To make the call, we will use [httpie](https://httpie.io/), which we installed already with the packages in the beginning

```
$ http post http://localhost:3030 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \  params:='{    
    "request_type": "call_function",    
    "finality": "final",    
    "account_id": "the_answer.testnet",    
    "method_name": "get_answer",    
    "args_base64": "e30="  
}'
```

#### Interact from across the world
If we try accessing the running service from outside of our server, it will fail because the service is only accessible from within our machine or the local network we are part of. While port forwarding is an option, setting up a reverse proxy is a much better approach.

**What is a reverse proxy?**
> *A reverse proxy is a server that sits before web servers and forwards client (e.g., web browser) requests to those web servers. Reverse proxies are typically implemented to help increase security, performance, and reliability*.
> [CloudFlare on proxies](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/cdn/glossary/reverse-proxy/)
Reverse Proxy with NGINX
[NGINX](https://www.nginx.com/) is an open-source web server that can also be used for load balancing, server caching and as a reverse proxy.



Now that we have a general idea of what *reverse proxy* is and how it would benefit our node, let's go ahead and Install nginx.

```
$ apt install nginx
```

We should create an nginx server config file in `/etc/nginx/sites-available/`
We can name the file anything we want, but usually, the name would be the domain name we are configuring.

*We can learn more about on nginx and configuration on the [nginx docs](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/web-server/reverse-proxy/)*

Let's go with `myRPC` with the following content

```
# content of /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRPC

server {
	listen 80;
	listen [::]:80;

	server_name YOUR_SERVER_IP_HERE; # or domain name if you have set one up

	location / {
    	proxy_pass http://localhost:3030;
    	include proxy_params;
	}
}
```

We can test our nginx config with the following command

```
$ nginx -t
```

After ensuring that our configurations are correct, we can enable our server by linking to it in the `sites-enabled` directory.

```
$ ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRpc /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/
$ systemctl restart nginx
```

We can use httpie from our personal computer (or anywhere in the world really) and interact with the node from outside of the local network of our server

```
$ http post http://123.123.123 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \
  params:='{
	"request_type": "call_function",
	"finality": "final",
	"account_id": "the_answer.testnet",
	"method_name": "get_answer",
	"args_base64": "e30="
  }'
```

A successfully returned query will include `"result":` with an array of bytes `[52, 50]` in JavaScript we can turn it into a human-readable string like so

```js
String.fromCharCode(...[52, 50])
'42'
```

#### Enabling SSL

If we already have a domain pointed to our server, enabling SSL can be relatively easy using guided tools such as [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org/).

We must use a Self-Signed Certificate if we need to get a domain name but want to add SSL to NGINX. Luckily, some articles cover this already, such as [this one](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-a-self-signed-ssl-certificate-for-nginx-in-ubuntu-20-04-1) from DigitalOcean.

After enabling SSL, our config file in `sites-available` would look something like this:

```
server {
	listen [::]:443 ssl ipv6only=on; # managed by Certbot
	listen 443 ssl; # managed by Certbot

	server_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # your domain here

	ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE/fullchain.pem; # managed by Certbot
	ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # managed by Certbot
	include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf; # managed by Certbot
	ssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem; # managed by Certbot

	location / {
    	proxy_pass http://localhost:3030;
	}
}

server {
	if ($host = YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE) {
    	return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
	} # managed by Certbot

	listen 80;
	listen [::]:80;

	server_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE;
	return 404; # managed by Certbot
}
```


#### Conclusion
In this article, we delved a bit into RPC nodes, which serve as pivotal connectors between applications and the blockchain.

At this point, we have a running node ready to use as a personal service. Before opening it to the public, we should secure the server further and implement rate limiting.

understanding-transactions-on-the-near-p:
## What is the NEAR Protocol Explorer?
Before we dive into the nitty-gritty, let’s get acquainted with the NEAR Protocol Explorer. Picture it as a high-tech crystal ball, offering a transparent view of all the activities happening on the NEAR blockchain. From transactions and accounts to contracts and changes in state, this explorer lets you peek into the blockchain’s soul without performing any dark magic. It’s user-friendly, accessible, and doesn’t require chanting in binary.
Key Definitions to Keep in Your Toolkit

**Transaction:** This is the backbone of the NEAR blockchain, a record that says, “Hey, something just happened!” Whether it’s transferring NEAR tokens, calling a smart contract, or creating a new account, transactions are the lifeblood of the blockchain’s functionality.
Account: Think of this as your digital identity on the NEAR platform. It’s where your tokens live and how you interact with smart contracts. Unlike traditional blockchains, NEAR accounts have human-readable names, not just a string of confusing characters.

**Block:** A bundle of transactions processed and recorded together. Blocks are chained together (hence, blockchain) to create a secure and unalterable ledger of all transactions.
Gas: No, not the kind you need to fill up your car. In NEAR, gas refers to the computational effort required to execute transactions. Think of it as the “fuel” for the blockchain.

**Smart Contract:** A self-executing contract with the terms of the agreement directly written into lines of code. It’s like a vending machine for transactions: input your request, and the contract automatically executes the agreed-upon outcome.

### Reading a Transaction: Step-by-Step

**1. Finding the Transaction**
Start your journey on the NEAR Protocol Explorer homepage. Here, you can search for a specific transaction by its hash (a unique identifier), or you can browse through blocks to discover recent transactions. It’s like being a blockchain detective, looking for clues in a digital landscape.

**2. Analyzing the Transaction Details**
Once you’ve clicked on a transaction, you’ll be greeted with a plethora of details. Here’s how to make sense of them:

- **Transaction Hash:** The unique identifier for this transaction. It’s like a fingerprint but for digital actions.

- **Sender:** The account that initiated the transaction. Think of it as the “from” address in a digital checkbook.

- **Receiver:** The account receiving the transaction. This could be another user or a smart contract.

- **Status:** Whether the transaction succeeded, failed, or is still pending. It’s the blockchain’s version of a delivery confirmation.

- **Timestamp:** The exact moment the transaction was processed—a digital timestamp for your blockchain activities.

- **Gas Used:** This tells you how much computational effort was required to execute the transaction. It’s like the receipt for the fuel your transaction consumed.

**3. Understanding the Transaction Type**
Transactions on NEAR can be as simple as transferring tokens or as complex as deploying a smart contract. By examining the transaction details, you can understand what action was performed. Each type has nuances, but the explorer provides clear descriptions to guide you through.

### Execution Details: A Closer Look

When a transaction is submitted to the NEAR blockchain, it goes through several steps:
Validation: Think of this as the entrance exam for your transaction. NEAR checks if your transaction has a valid signature (like a correct password) and if you have enough balance to pay for the transaction’s gas cost (like checking if you have enough fuel in your car).

**Routing:** Your transaction then takes a trip to its designated shard. NEAR uses sharding to split the network into manageable pieces, making everything faster and more scalable.

**Execution:** This is where the magic happens. The NEAR network processes it according to what your transaction aims to do (like transferring tokens or executing a smart contract). This processing involves running the specific code of your transaction and updating the blockchain’s state to reflect the change.

The execution detail of a transaction, therefore, encompasses the steps taken by the blockchain to validate, route, and execute the transaction, including any changes made to the state and the computational resources consumed to perform these actions.

### Tips for the Novice NEAR Explorer Detective

- **Keep It Simple:** Start with basic transactions, like transfers, to familiarize yourself with the explorer’s layout.

- **Use Filters:** Leverage the explorer’s filtering tools to narrow your search. It’s like using a magnifying glass to find the necessary clue.

- **Explore Smart Contracts:** Be bold and dive into smart contract transactions. They offer a fascinating glimpse into the programmable side of NEAR.

Congratulations! You’ve just decrypted the basics of reading and understanding transactions on the NEAR Protocol Explorer.

### One More Byte: Understanding Gas

**Gas** is essentially the fuel that powers transactions on NEAR. It covers the computational efforts required to validate, route, and execute transactions. Here’s a breakdown:

**Purpose:** Gas limits the work needed to process transactions, protects the network from potential abuse, and ensures a fair resource allocation among users. This fee is paid to validators as a reward for processing transactions and securing the network.

**Gas Price:** The cost of gas varies based on network demand and is set by validators. You can think of it as surge pricing in ride-sharing apps, where the cost increases with demand.

**Gas Limit:** When you initiate a transaction, you’ll set a maximum gas limit you’re willing to use. It’s a way to control your spending and avoid unexpected costs. The default is often 300 Tgas.

**Gas Usage and Refunds**
After executing your transaction, the actual gas used is tallied up. If it’s less than your limit, NEAR refunds the difference. This process makes transactions efficient and economical, as you only pay for the resources you use.

### For Users and Developers

- Users should learn to adjust gas limits and prices to optimize their transaction costs.

- Developers need to write gas-efficient code, especially for complex operations that could guzzle up computational resources. 30% of gas fees spent on the contract execution will go to a contract’s account itself; simply using it will bring some income. Due to the cheap gas cost, this will make a significant impact only for the most popular and often-called contracts, but it’s nice to have such an option nonetheless.

community-call-9-recap-3082:
**MODERATORS:** Owen Hassall
**VIDEO:** https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nNMeudZL2Pc

## AGENDA
- Presentation of ZKLogin from vSelf
- How to integrate verifiable credentials with Reclaim Protocol 
- Discussion around the new NEAR ZK Light Client from RISC Zero
- NDC Private Voting
- Discussion of Zero Knowledge Machine Learning

## NOTES
- **Presentation of ZKLogin from vSelf:** We had a presentation from vSelf regarding ZKLogin an innovative approach to private onboarding to decentralized applications and on-chain communities. Slides can be found [HERE](https://docsend.com/view/mjsxwxwv9sct3zba).

- **Demonstration from Reclaim Protocol:** Next we had a demonstration from Reclaim Protocol which recently received a grant from DevHub. It was really interesting to see how one can use third party applications that a user has already been KYC'd on, such as Coinbase, to generate KYC for another application. 

- **RISC Zero's ZK Light Client:** We then heard from RISC Zero regarding the NEAR Light Client they have produced that can generate proofs of a block in one minute.

- **ZKML and Private Voting Discussion:** After that, we delved into a more informal discussion around the hot topic of ZKML and ZK private voting mechanics.

## ACTION ITEMS
- If you have an open source project building on NEAR please add your repositories to the Electron Capital report. This gives us an opportunity to showcase the amazing projects building in the ecosystem and bring in more devs! The report can be found [HERE](https://github.com/electric-capital/crypto-ecosystems/blob/master/data/ecosystems/n/near.toml).

near-dev-news-2-3192:
Greetings and welcome to NEAR Dev NEWS, your go-to source for the latest developments in the NEAR Developer ecosystem! NEAR Blockchain serves as the foundational layer for all blockchain applications, providing an open-source operating system that empowers developers to create fully decentralized apps interoperable with any blockchain. Our Digest offers an overview of the progress made by developers within the NEAR Ecosystem and highlights technical updates shaping the blockchain operating system.

Fresh off of ETH Denver, we have lots of news and some exciting updates. But before we get into them , we will like you to partake in a quick survey about the current Developer Experience on NEAR.  Please take the time to fill it out and play a pivotal role in shaping the ecosystem. Your feedback will provide valuable info to builders and contributors, paving the way for FRPs on **DevHub**. 

#### [CLICK HERE TO FILL SURVEY 🏆](https://bit.ly/devhub-survey-q1-2024).

Thank you for taking the survey, now let’s get into the updates!


  
### FEATURED RELEASES 🤩

- `near-discovery` [Released on 02-27-2024](https://github.com/near/near-discovery/releases/tag/02-27-2024): near.org Decentralized Frontend Gateway.  Alpha testers are needed , more info in "CALL FOR CONTRIBUTORS / OPPORTUNITIES" section.
- `VM` [Released version 2.6.0](https://github.com/NearSocial/VM/releases/tag/2.6.0): VM execution layer for decentralized frontend components.
- `near-sdk-rs` [Released version near-sdk-v5.0.0](https://github.com/near/near-sdk-rs/releases/tag/near-sdk-v5.0.0): Rust SDK for writing smart contracts.
- `bos-cli-rs` [Command line utility for developing decentralized frontend components - Version 0.8.1](https://github.com/near/near-cli-rs/releases/tag/v0.8.1).


- Discover more in releases and merged pull requests in our changelog 👉 [here](https://docs.near.org/changelog/2024/02/29/#-documentation).


  
### DEVELOPER UPDATES 🛠

- Exciting news! `near-sdk-rs` has just hit the milestone of its 5.0 release, perfectly timed for the EthDenver Hackathon. Learn more about this significant achievement 👉 [here](https://twitter.com/NEARDevHub/status/1761055161005359297).

- `devhub.near` has been already upgraded to [near-sdk-rs 5.0](https://github.com/near/near-sdk-rs/releases/tag/near-sdk-v5.0.0) and deployed to production using [cargo-near](https://github.com/near/cargo-near).

- `Near Social` was upgraded to VM 2.6.0. Click 👉 [here](https://twitter.com/ekuzyakov/status/1762681659151749358?s=46) to learn more. 

- We're transitioning from a deploy script to manual deployment by users, enabling account creation and deployment through specific commands like `near create-account <accountId.testnet> --useFaucet` and `near deploy <accountId.testnet> <wasmFile>`.

- Configuration for the bos-workspace GitHub workflow now utilizes non-archival RPC. Find out more 👉 [here](https://github.com/NEARBuilders/bos-workspace/blob/main/.github/workflows/deploy.yml).

- Curious about creating a new Rust application on NEAR Protocol? Check out this informative [tutorial](https://youtu.be/JAspXvOmTTY?si=iLoeHG5kd21DFEkZ&t=77).

- Updates have been implemented for cross-contract calls in NEAR docs, hello near example, and quickstart in near docs. See 👉 [here](https://docs.near.org/).

- Documentation team exploring the possibility of a tutorial on utilizing workspaces-js with Rust contracts for developers.

- Updated documentation on [Chain Signatures](https://docs.near.org/concepts/abstraction/chain-signatures) now includes guidance on which API to use for dev-based chain abstraction.

- Indexer ETL & OpenAI powered NLP on NEAR , Courtesy of PrimeLab. Read more 👉 [here](https://gov.near.org/t/announcement-indexer-etl-openai-powered-nlp-on-near-by-primelab/18487).

- Send ETH with 1 Near TX. Click 👉 [here](https://twitter.com/mattdlockyer/status/1762964787385061618?s=46) to learn more.

- Get a sneak peak at real life applications of Chain Abstraction with our latest 👉 [tweet](https://twitter.com/neardevhub/status/1763268978410230267?s=46).

-  [OpenCann's] Wallet Selector has been updated(https://opencann.net/)

- Celebrate Meteor wallet's massive milestone: 100k shard dog NFTs minted within 5 days! Read more 👉 [here](https://x.com/chrestomanzi/status/1759180564702150772?s=46).

- Explore the amazing projects within the NEAR Ecosystem through our 👉 [NEAR Catalog](https://near.social/nearcatalog.near/widget/Index).

- Introducing FASTNEAR! Discover The fastest infrastructure for NEARProtocol 👉 [here](https://twitter.com/NEARProtocol).

- `Tip`: Stay informed: Plans are underway to remove (https://docs.near.org/tools/welcome) during the SDK rs5.0.0 migration, expected in the upcoming month. Please refer to (https://docs.near.org/develop/welcome) for the latest updates.

- `Tip`: Keep utilizing `near_sdk::collections` for `UnorderedMap` and `UnorderedSet` . Stay tuned for more collections coming soon 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/near-sdk-rs/issues/1134#issuecomment-1961674485).


  
### UPDATES ON NEP'S ✅
- [NEP-330: Build details extension](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/533) - Contract standards Update | **5th March 2024**

- [NEP-393: Add class metadata interface](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/528) - Contract Standards Update | **26th Feb 2024**

- [NEP-519: Support for yielded execution](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/519) - Protocol Update | **1st march 2024**

- [NEP-491: Non-Refunable Storage](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/491) - Protocol Update | **26th Feb 2024**

- [NEP-483: Prefix Tag for signed messages](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/483) - Protocol Update | **26th Feb 2024**

- [NEP413: Fixed links to Examples](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/535) | **1st March 2024**




  
### STAKEWARS 🚀
- ```cargo build --package neard --features statelessnet_protocol --release``` ensures that your node is built with the necessary features to align with the updated protocol version, thus preventing protocol version mismatches and node panics.

- Validators were guided on how to check the current version of their node to verify if it matches the desired version. The command shared to check the current version of the node is : `~/nearcore/target/release/neard --version`.

- Users were provided with instructions on how to fetch the latest statelessnet git tag to ensure they are using the most recent version.

-  Users can submit bug reports for rewards 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md#2-bug-bounty).

- Users can now submit traffic generation proposals for rewards 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md#3-traffic-generation).

- Community validator nodes have been onboarding with StatelessNet.

- Wallet is now supported on [StatelssNet](https://statelessnet.mynearwallet.com).


  
### DEVREL'S 🥑
- `Community Calls`: Next Tools Community Call will be on 6th of March 5PM UTC. Moderated by Lyudmil. [Meeting Link](https://tinyurl.com/tools-community-call-4).

- `Work Group Calls`:  Next Protocol Work Group Call for [NEP-519](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/519) will be on 8th of March 4PM UTC. Moderated by Victor. [Meeting Link](https://bit.ly/protocol-work-group-call-8).

- `ETHDenver`: Our presence at ETHDenver was a hit! We saw a remarkable turnout with 17 hackathon submissions, 5 of which truly stood out for their exceptional quality.

- `ETHDenver`: Our DevHub DevRel team got great feedback for their outstanding engagement efforts. From providing top-tier technical support to distributing swag, they were instrumental in making the event a success.

- `ETHDenver`: Remote technical support was seamless and effective. With quick response times and high-quality assistance, we ensured every hacker felt supported and empowered throughout the event.

- `ETHDenver`: Our commitment doesn't end with the event. We're excited to maintain the momentum by engaging with hackers post-event through the NEAR ETH Denver hackers Telegram group.


  
### CALL FOR CONTRIBUTORS 📞

- NEAR DevHub releases Developer Survey. Please take the time to fill it and play a pivotal role in shaping the ecosystem. Your feedback will provide valuable info to builders and contributors paving the way for FRPs on DevHub. Click [here](https://bit.ly/devhub-survey-q1-2024).

- We've initiated alpha testing the BOS web engine for creating decentralized front end components on NEAR. Get involved today by following this [link](https://github.com/near/bos-web-engine).

- Open Challenge to create a more engaging video on how to get started with @rustlang SDK for @NEARProtocol. Tag @NEARDevHub_ on twitter upon completion.

- Given the release of the new SDK , both docs and example repositories need updating. If you want to contribute , [join the Docs Community Group](https://near.social/devgovgigs.near/widget/gigs-board.pages.community.activity?handle=documentation).

- Join the StatelessNet Traffic Generation Reward Program. Early submissions are encouraged! Details 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md).

- Check out [DevHub's On-Chain Quests](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=challenges) ⛳️, where you'll find a dynamic array of challenges across various communities, earning recognition and respect as you conquer each one! 






  
# UPCOMING EVENTS 

### ASIA:

- March 26, 2024 - March 27, 2024 | WOW Summit | Hong Kong 
- March 27, 2024 - March 28, 2024  | [BUIDL Asia | Seoul, Korea](https://www.buidl.asia/) | KryptoSeoul 👉 NEAR Foundation and Korea Hub will be present at the event 
- March 29, 2024 - March 31, 2024 | [ETH Seoul | Seoul, Korea](http://www.ethseoul.org/) | KryptoSeoul, Dystopia Labs 👉 DevHub and NEARWEEK will be present at the event 

### EUROPE

- March 8, 2024 - March 11, 2024 | [ETHOxford](https://ethoxford.io/#home) 👉 DevHub DevRels / NEAR Campus will be present at the event.
- March 14, 2024 | [Pragma London | London, UK](https://ethglobal.com/events/pragma-london) | ETHGlobal 👉 NEAR Foundation will be speaking.
- March 15, 2024 | Crypto Bootcamp w/ Polygon| Paris, France
- March 15, 2024 - March 17, 2024 | [ETHGlobal London | London, UK](https://ethglobal.com/events/london2024) | ETHGlobal 👉 DevHub will be present at the event 
- March 18, 2024 | Crypto Bootcamp w/ Polygon | London, UK
- March 18, 2024 - March 20, 2024 | [Digital Asset Summit 2024 | London](https://www.blockworks.co/) | London, UK | Blockworks
- March 18, 2024 - March 22, 2024 | [GDC](https://gdconf.com/) | San Francisco
- March 23, 2024 - March 24, 2024 | [Money Motion 2024](https://moneymotion.com/) | Zagreb, Croatia | Money Motion
- March 27, 2024 - March 30, 2024 | [ETH Bucharest | Bucharest, Romania](https://www.ethbucharest.xyz/) | ETH Bucharest 👉 DevHub will be present at the event 
- March 18, 2024 - March 20, 2024 | [Digital Asset Summit](https://www.blockworks.co/) | London | Blockworks

### SOUTH AMERICA

- March 22nd - March 24 | [ETHSamba](https://ethsamba.org/) | Brazil 👉 DevHub DevRels / NEAR Campus will be present at the event

### THE UNITED STATES 

- March 12, 2024 | [/brandnew @ SXSW](https://www.sxsw.com/) | Austin, TX | Boys Club 👉 Jarrod Barnes will be speaking 
- March 20, 2024 - March 22, 2024 | IWB 2024 | DC area

## SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENTS

near-dev-news-3-3193:
Greetings and welcome to NEAR Dev NEWS, your go-to source for the latest developments in the NEAR Developer ecosystem! NEAR Blockchain serves as the foundational layer for all blockchain applications, providing an open-source operating system that empowers developers to create fully decentralized apps interoperable with any blockchain. Our Digest offers an overview of the progress made by developers within the NEAR Ecosystem and highlights technical updates shaping the blockchain operating system.

Before we kick into updates for the new week, we have two spotlight announcements we would like you to partake in:

**📋 Developer Experience Survey**: Please take the time to fill it out and play a pivotal role in shaping the ecosystem. Your feedback will provide valuable info to builders and contributors, paving the way for FRPs on **DevHub**. 

###### [CLICK HERE TO FILL SURVEY 🏆](https://bit.ly/devhub-survey-q1-2024).

But that's not all! As part of the excitement for the new week, don't miss out on the upcoming Hackbox Workshop happening this Wednesday **(NEAR HACKER HOUSE)**, featuring a mini hackathon and amazing prizes for participants. Click 👉[here](https://www.eventbrite.com/e/near-hacker-house-and-mini-hackathon-tickets-850773866537?utm_experiment=test_share_listing&aff=ebdsshios) for more details.

Thank you for participating, now let’s get into the updates!


  
### FEATURED RELEASES & PR's 🤩

- `near-discovery` [Released on 02-27-2024](https://github.com/near/near-discovery/releases/tag/02-27-2024): near.org Decentralized Frontend Gateway.  Alpha testers are needed , more info in "CALL FOR CONTRIBUTORS / OPPORTUNITIES" section.
- `VM` [Released version 2.6.0](https://github.com/NearSocial/VM/releases/tag/2.6.0): VM execution layer for decentralized frontend components.
- `near-sdk-rs` [Released version near-sdk-v5.0.0](https://github.com/near/near-sdk-rs/releases/tag/near-sdk-v5.0.0): Rust SDK for writing smart contracts.
- `bos-cli-rs` [Command line utility for developing decentralized frontend components - Version 0.8.1](https://github.com/near/near-cli-rs/releases/tag/v0.8.1).
- `near-api-js`: [Fix delegate schema #1314](https://github.com/near/near-api-js/pull/1314) : In response to an issue hindering meta-transaction creation, a PR was swiftly merged, fixing a serialization error in transaction relay.


- Discover more in releases and merged pull requests in our changelog 👉 [here](https://docs.near.org/changelog/2024/02/29/#-documentation).


  
### DEVELOPER UPDATES 🛠

- `Work Group Calls`: NEAR Protocol Working Group met for the 8th time and voted to **approve** NEP-519. This introduces the capability for smart contracts in the NEAR protocol to delay responding to callers until observing future transactions, addressing situations where immediate responses are not feasible. 👉 [NEP-519](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/519).

- Addressing Recent User Experience Challenges on NEAR Protocol: A Plan for Resolving Transaction Congestion 👉 [Twitter Thread](https://twitter.com/BowenWang18/status/1765956167149420588).

- We're exploring `RustPython` and `near-sys` integration for Python contract development on NEAR. Check out the proof-of-concept 👉 [here](https://github.com/frol/near-contract-python-proof-of-concept).

- Discussions for the replacement of the widely used `wee_alloc` package were had. Options for potential replacements include `dlmalloc-rs`, `talc`, and others.

- Get a hands on experience with `NEAR-SDK-RS 5.0` release and assist fellow developers in the ecosystem. Contribute to updating examples 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/docs/issues/1744).

- Participate in discussions on Reddit to share your opinions and insights: 👉 [Reddit Discussion](https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/s/iyxBQbkJEA).

- We're considering renewing the `NEAR SDK JS` **fellowship program**. Share your thoughts and suggestions for improvements in the [Tools Community](https://t.me/NEAR_Tools_Community_Group). Focus areas include Developer experience and ensuring timely releases.

- Discover [@tryjutsu](https://twitter.com/tryjutsu)'s generative UI platform simplifying Web3 app development. Over 400 components built at Eth Denver. Learn more [here](https://x.com/jarednotjerry1/status/1765147621453090975?s=20).

- Learn about NEAR Protocol's 10x Faster Stateless Validation 👉 [Twitter Thread](https://twitter.com/prophet_node/status/1767597135615160819)

-  Discover new tools like [shuttle.rs](https://www.shuttle.rs/) and explore their potential for NEAR development. Share your experiences and insights on using these tools.[Tools Community](https://t.me/NEAR_Tools_Community_Group).

- Explore the newly launched **FASTNEAR API**: 👉 [GitHub](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs).

- NEAR expands to support multi-chain experiences. Check out [@SweatEconomy](https://twitter.com/SweatEconomy)'s demo of BNB on BSC Chain from a NEAR wallet 👉 [here](https://x.com/jarednotjerry1/status/1765147620064850228?s=20).

- Ongoing development in DAO tooling, with plans for a comprehensive resource for DAOs. Integrated Announcements and Discussions on DevHub. Explore more 👉 [here](https://x.com/jarednotjerry1/status/1765147624531767479?s=20).

- Take a look at the technical overview of Protocol infrastructure through the onboarding series: 👉 [YouTube Playlist](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL9tzQn_TEuFXBfQj5sXBcvp6OWzdjgB7I).

- Explore `near-api-js` updates and signing messages guidance in the [near-api-js Cookbook](https://github.com/near/near-api-js/blob/master/packages/cookbook/utils/verify-signature.js).

- New documentation example [Create a Chain Signature example](https://docs.near.org/abstraction/chain-signatures?_gl=1*16wl4al*_ga*MjA4NDgwNzc5NS4xNjY2ODcwODgw*_ga_9GWCXQJ62J*MTcxMDI1MDM0Ni4xODUuMC4xNzEwMjUwMzQ3LjU5LjAuMA..) has been addded. 

- Updated documentation on [Chain Signatures](https://docs.near.org/concepts/abstraction/chain-signatures) now includes guidance on which API to use for dev-based chain abstraction.

- A First Look at Chain Signatures: Cross-Chain Without Bridges 👉 [Article](https://medium.com/@ProximityFi/a-first-look-at-chain-signatures-cross-chain-without-bridges-81c8421d153c).

- SDK documentation deprecation task ongoing during SDK RS5.0.0 migration, expected to conclude within a month, in favor of a single source to avoid confusion and streamline learning.

- Configuration for the bos-workspace GitHub workflow now utilizes non-archival RPC. Find out more 👉 [here](https://github.com/NEARBuilders/bos-workspace/blob/main/.github/workflows/deploy.yml).

- Join the discussion on developing a Query workspace tool similar to BOS workspace. Contribute your ideas 👉 [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1h92VD6XGZWuR_BbL89brOIa1RJ5BtYuSneEW7rLSMFU/edit#heading=h.tjzmabi7kftx).

- Join the discussion on the potential for a chat bot with NEAR payment capabilities, dubbed "NearGpt". 👉 [Tools Community](https://t.me/NEAR_Tools_Community_Group).

- Interested in running a node yourself ? Join the [Community Run Nodes TG group](https://t.me/communityNodes).

- [Near hacks hackathon](https://nearhacks.hackerearth.com/). Hosted by NEAR India and Devhub concluded with a total of 1500+ participants registered. 

- Celebrate as NEAR DevHub announces the creation of 100 million NEAR accounts since mainnet launch.

- `Tip`: Engage with the  [Documentation Community](https://t.me/neardocscg) for updates, clarifications, and alignment with actual usage and best practices.

- `Tip`: If you run a TESTNET validator node, please update it to the 1.38 version: https://github.com/near/nearcore/releases/tag/1.38.0-rc.2. Currently voting for this release is blocked due to insufficient nodes running the version. The 1.38.0-rc.2 is only to be used on TESTNET.

- `Tip`: Utilize free RPC servers like LavaNet if encountering RPC server load issues.

- `Tip`: Keep utilizing `near_sdk::collections` for `UnorderedMap` and `UnorderedSet` . Stay tuned for more collections coming soon 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/near-sdk-rs/issues/1134#issuecomment-1961674485).

- `Tip`: **New to NEAR? 👨‍💻 :** Whether you're familiar with Rust , JS, or simply eager to contribute to NEAR tooling, begin your journey with comprehensive NEAR docs and DevHub resources 👇:

1. NEAR docs: [Link](https://docs.near.org/)
2. DevHub: [Link](https://neardevhub.org/)
3. Join the Community: Have questions? Join the lively discussions in [neardev](https://t.me/neardev) Telegram group.
4. Office Hours: Get personalized assistance during our [DevHub Office Hours](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=devrel&tab=office-hours).
5. Tutorial: Watch this beginner-friendly tutorial on NEAR: [How to Create a Token on NEAR](https://youtu.be/cpODrAYiZKc?si=nCwVoZHPQ_razHyY).


  
### RECENTLY UPDATED NEP'S ✅

**APPROVED NEPs**: 

A successful NEP is one that addresses a specific problem or needs within the NEAR ecosystem. These are the NEPs that were approved by the protocol workgroup this week:

- [NEP-519: Support for yielded execution](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/519) - Protocol Update | **8th march 2024**
- [NEP-491: Non-Refunable Storage](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/491) - Protocol Update | **26th Feb 2024**
  

**REVIEW STAGE**:

Subject matter experts are currently reviewing the following NEPs. Some of the working group members are also deciding whether accept or reject them. Feel free to explore, these NEPs will aid you during your development as you integrate with your dApps. share your thoughts and leave a comment.

- [NEP-330: Build details extension](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/533) - Contract standards Update | **5th March 2024**
- [NEP-393: Add class metadata interface](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/528) - Contract Standards Update | **26th Feb 2024**
- [NEP-483: Prefix Tag for signed messages](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/483) - Protocol Update | **26th Feb 2024**


To learn more about NEP's click [here](https://github.com/near/NEPs/blob/master/neps/nep-0001.md) 
To view all the NEP's click [here](https://github.com/orgs/near/projects/51/views/1)


  
### STAKEWARS 🚀

Participating in Stakewars? Here are some quick news and notes you should be aware of.

- ```cargo build --package neard --features statelessnet_protocol --release``` ensures that your node is built with the necessary features to align with the updated protocol version, thus preventing protocol version mismatches and node panics.

- Validators were guided on how to check the current version of their node to verify if it matches the desired version. The command shared to check the current version of the node is : `~/nearcore/target/release/neard --version`.

- Users were provided with instructions on how to fetch the latest statelessnet git tag to ensure they are using the most recent version.

-  Users can submit bug reports for rewards 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md#2-bug-bounty).

- Users can now submit traffic generation proposals for rewards 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md#3-traffic-generation).

- Community validator nodes have been onboarding with StatelessNet.

- Wallet is now supported on [StatelssNet](https://statelessnet.mynearwallet.com).





  
### CALL FOR CONTRIBUTORS 📞

- We've initiated alpha testing the BOS web engine for creating decentralized front end components on NEAR. Discover more by following this [Github](https://github.com/near/bos-web-engine).

- Open Challenge to create a more engaging video on how to get started with @rustlang SDK for @NEARProtocol. Tag @NEARDevHub_ on twitter upon completion.

- Given the release of the new SDK , both docs and example repositories need updating. If you want to contribute , [join the Docs Community Group](https://near.social/devgovgigs.near/widget/gigs-board.pages.community.activity?handle=documentation).

- Join the StatelessNet Traffic Generation Reward Program. Early submissions are encouraged! Details 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/stakewars-iv/blob/main/REWARDS.md).

- Check out [DevHub's On-Chain Quests](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=challenges) ⛳️, where you'll find a dynamic array of challenges across various communities, earning recognition and respect as you conquer each one!

near-dev-news-12-3230:
**Welcome to the 12th edition of NEAR Dev NEWS!** 🎉 We're thrilled to highlight some significant updates in NEAR's documentation tailored for the NEAR COMMUNITY. This edition is packed with exciting developments aimed at enhancing your developer experience. Read more to discover our latest initiative: the **Bounty Boost Program**, crafted to incentivize and reward web2 and web3 developers who participate and win hackathons utilizing NEAR tools. 
  

### FEATURED RELEASES & PR's 🤩

- 🎉 **`create-near-app v7.0.0`** has been released 🎉:

This new version makes it optional to use NEAR components (aka BOS Components) when creating a Web Application. Another change is that now all pages leverage a React Context to share a common wallet as well as the AccountId when a user is logged-in. Please try it and let us know if anything is not working as expected 👉 [here](https://github.com/near/create-near-app)

- New release of `near-sdk-contract-tools`, now supports `near-sdk@5.1`. You can find more information about the release 👉[here](https://twitter.com/sudo_build/status/1788176556277616884).

- **`near-jsonrpc-client-rs`** Version 0.9.0 has been released:
   - A new release of `near-jsonrpc-client-rs` version 0.9.0 was announced. This release includes improvements to the RPC server in nearcore. The update was credited to a specific contributor and was accompanied by gratitude for testing and final tweaks before release.
   - Check it out on 👉 [GitHub](https://github.com/near/near-jsonrpc-client-rs/releases/tag/0.9.0)

- 🚀 [**`near.cli.rs`**](https://near.cli.rs/) has new releases [0.9.0](https://github.com/near/near-cli-rs/releases/tag/v0.9.0) and [0.9.1](https://github.com/near/near-cli-rs/releases/tag/v0.9.1)
Enjoy even more help from CLI selecting the functions to interact if the contract supports NEAR ABI!

- Discover more in releases and merged pull requests in our **changelog** 👉 [here](https://docs.near.org/changelog/2024/02/29/#-documentation).


  
### DEVELOPER UPDATES 🛠

- **New Documentation feature:**

Code Navigator was released on docs 🚨🎉, A new tool in docs that's able to better explain code-related concepts! Please check it and give us feedback so we can improve it! Click 👉[here](https://docs.near.org/build/smart-contracts/anatomy/).

- **Cross-Linking Enhancement Proposal:** 

Community member proposed cross-linking between READMEs of core-contracts and examples repositories to enhance navigation and context. Agreement was reached to ensure mutual referencing between examples and core contracts, facilitating clarity and understanding for users.

-  **NFT Zero to Hero Tutorial Update Inquiry:**

A Developer highlighted outdated content in the NFT zero to hero JavaScript tutorial and inquired about ongoing efforts to update it. Discussion touched upon previous discussions regarding code organization and potential solutions, with a mention of separating tutorials by language and consolidating examples.

- **NEAR Developer Experience Appreciation:**

  Developer expressed satisfaction with NEAR developer experience improvements, highlighting tools like Cargo Near, Near-CLI-RS, the new SDK, and documentation. 

- **SDK Documentation Migration:**

   - Ecosystem leaders are actively migrating all contract SDK documentation into a single location, enhancing accessibility and usability. This effort includes consolidating information on basics, state/storage, functions, and interfaces.
   - Links to migrated documentation:
     - [Basics Documentation](https://docs-preview-pr-1919.onrender.com/build/smart-contracts/anatomy/)
     - [State/Storage Documentation](https://docs-preview-pr-1919.onrender.com/build/smart-contracts/anatomy/functions)
     - [Functions and Interface Documentation](https://docs-preview-pr-1919.onrender.com/build/smart-contracts/anatomy/functions)

Check out this article authored by the maintainers of NEAR API JS! It provides a comprehensive guide on developing React applications integrated with NEAR. 👉 [NEAR API JS React App Guide](https://www.reddit.com/r/nearprotocol/comments/1ctcma6/build_your_first_react_app_that_interact_with/)
 
- **Testnet Transaction Viewing Issues:**

Developer reported issues with viewing transactions from accounts on testnet and received assistance from a community member.
  
- **create-near-app v7.0.0 Release Announcement:**

Community member announced the release of create-near-app v7.0.0, mentioning optional NEAR components and React Context integration.
  
- **Formal Verification Tooling Support Request:**

Developer expressed interest in connecting with NEAR Foundation/grants team for support with formal verification tooling.
  
- **UI Near Component Library Announcement:**

 Community member announced the availability of the UI Near component library, shared a link for feedback, and discussed Tailwind usage. The shared link was: [UI is Near](https://www.uiisnear.xyz/)
  
- **On-chain Bounty Inquiry**

Developer inquired about bounty support in DAOs, and community members discussed on-chain bounty options.Link: [Heroes Build](https://heroes.build/)

- **Sample Code Repositories:**

   - GitHub repositories for auction examples and storage examples have been shared within the community, providing developers with useful code snippets and resources.
   - [Auction Examples Repository](https://github.com/near-examples/auction-examples)
   - [Storage Examples Repository](https://github.com/near-examples/storage-examples)


- **Developer Tools Optimization:**

   - Efforts towards dependencies cleanup and potential refactoring of NEAR crates are underway. This initiative will streamline dependencies, reduce unnecessary ones, and introduce robust CI/CD workflows.
   - [Issue #8888](https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/8888) outlines ongoing efforts towards dependency management and cleanup within NEAR crates.

-  **New Framework for Indexers: inindexer:**

[inindexer](https://github.com/INTEARnear/inindexer) is a new framework that allows you to build your own custom indexer to react to the transactions and other events on chain (Examples are included). Kudos to [Slimedragon](https://near.org/near/widget/ProfilePage?accountId=slimedragon.near) for releasing it! Learn more about the indexers concept and other available solutions in [NEAR Docs](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/indexers)

- **Pagoda:** 

Pagoda is going through a Privacy Assessment exercise with an external company. This officially kicked off last week and will be going until July. The goal is to help better support users with their privacy rights/needs but also identify and manage potential  privacy risks. We are following the NIST Privacy Framework in that respect.

- **Pagoda:**

 Pagoda is kicking off audits for Chain Signatures and the Multichain Gas Relayer. This is something that will be completed prior to the products launching on mainnet.

- **DevHub Recaps:**

If you missed out on the insightful discussions, You can catch up on all the key takeaways and highlights by checking out the recaps here: 

[Documentation Community Call #9 Recap](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jt1JWWttCcs)
[Tools Community Call #6 Recap](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=tooling&tab=community-calls)

- **DevHub Livestream:**

DevHub Live hosted a session diving into the Near ecosystem, exploring its tooling and community. Boris, a guest, discussed the upcoming ETH Berlin event and highlighted Near's participation. Catch up on the recap [here](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=blog&id=3295)

- **Work Groups:**

The protocol work group prepares to have its 10th work group meeting to discuss NEP-522, an important proposal addressing nonce behavior within the Near Protocol. NEP-522 aims to streamline transaction nonce management, offering a more efficient and user-friendly approach for developers. Developers are invited to join the discussion. Click 👉[here](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/522).

  
### THIS WEEKS TIPS 💡

`Tip`: For key management in NEAR development, it's suggested to focus efforts on improving `cli-rs` instead of `cli-js`.

`Tip`: When calling a contract using `near-api-js`, it's generally preferred to set up the account object (account.functionCall()) instead of the contract object (contract.method_name()), as the former is less confusing for developers.

`Tip`: To ensure consistent and reproducible builds across computers, developers can use "cargo near build" which aims to link compiled wasm contracts with their code, enabling consistent builds.

`Tip`: **New to NEAR? 👨‍💻 :** Whether you're familiar with Rust , JS, or simply eager to contribute to NEAR tooling, begin your journey with comprehensive NEAR docs and DevHub resources 👇:

### DEVELOPER OPPORTUNITIES

- 🏆 **NEAR Bounty Booster Program Announcement:** 🏆
The NEAR Bounty Booster initiative has been launched to support hackers who use the NEAR stack in non-sponsored hackathons. By matching winnings up to $5,000, the program. The program is applicable to both Web2 and Web3 Hackathons ⭐️
[Learn more](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=blog&id=3021)

- Feature your project in our weekly newsletter by checking out this page https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=neardevnews&tab=how-to-get-featured

- NEAR Horizon 2 Cohort invites developers like you to step into scaling decentralized applications. More details 👉[here](https://twitter.com/nearhorizon/status/1768310840120189123).

- We've initiated alpha testing the BOS web engine for creating decentralized front end components on NEAR. Get involved today by following this [link](https://bwe-docs.near.dev/).


  
### RECENTLY UPDATED NEP'S ✅

**APPROVED NEPs:**

A successful NEP is one that addresses a specific problem or needs within the NEAR ecosystem. These are the NEPs that were approved by the protocol workgroup this week:

- [NEP-330: Build details extension](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/533) - Contract standards Update 
- [NEP-536: Reduce the number of refund receipts](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/536) - Protocol Update
  

**UPCOMING NEPs:**

   - [Issue #8888](https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/8888) outlines ongoing efforts towards dependency management and cleanup within NEAR crates.

6. **Developer Community Engagement:**
   - The Tools Community Call #6 is scheduled for May 14th, 2024, inviting you to participate, share updates, and discuss projects.
   - [Join the Community Call](https://bit.ly/tools-call-6-meet)

7. **UI for NEAR Project Progress:**
   - Significant progress has been made on the UI for NEAR project, with 75% of components ready and 40% of documentation completed. The full component library is expected to be ready for use by the end of the following week.



8. **Serialization Clarifications:**
   - Discussions have clarified the usage of NearToken and U128 for serialization purposes, ensuring efficient handling of data structures in contracts.

9. **Developer Queries Resolution:**
   - Queries regarding the serialization of u64/u128 in structs and the necessity of creating separate structs for storing in contracts and returning as function outputs have been addressed within the community. It was clarified that it's not necessary to create separate structs for storing in contracts and returning as function outputs. Instead, developers can use the **NearToken** struct for both cases and implement JSON and Borsh serialization for this single struct. **NearToken** is serialized as a native u128 for Borsh and as a string-encoded number for JSON, ensuring efficient serialization for both formats. This resolution simplifies development processes and ensures consistency in handling u64/u128 data types within contracts.

10. **SDK Review and Discussions:**
   - Ongoing discussions and reviews of tools and libraries such as near-api-js have taken place, focusing on best practices for contract calling methods and key management approaches.

11. **cargo-near Build Tool Development:**
    - Development of the `cargo-near build` tool is in progress to assist with reproducible builds and linking compiled wasm contracts with their code, providing solutions for consistent builds across different computers.
    - 👉[GitHub Pull Request #134](https://github.com/near/cargo-near/pull/134) outlines the ongoing development and testing process.

12. **SDK Version Compatibility:**
    - Updates have been made to SDK versions to ensure compatibility with the latest tools and libraries, facilitating smoother development workflows.

13. **Pagoda:** 
- Improved QueryAPI logging system and DB connection pooling resulting in ~2-10 times better indexing performance.
- KitWallet has been migrated to use QueryAPI for Access Keys indexer, making it more reliable for wallets that still use KitWallet.
- QueryAPI hit all-time-high of 1.05M requests on April 26th, peaking at 400 req/second with ~250ms 95th percentile and ~15ms median GraphQL response time.

14. **Automated Verification Processes:**
    - Plans for automation of `cargo-near` verify processes are in place to streamline developer workflows and enhance code verification efficiency.

15. **Developer Feedback Solicitation:**
    - Developers have been encouraged to provide feedback on tools, libraries, and documentation to drive continuous improvement and enhance the developer experience.

16: **New Framework for Indexers: inindexer:**
- [inindexer](https://github.com/INTEARnear/inindexer) is a new framework that allows you to build your own custom indexer to react to the transactions and other events on chain (Examples are included). Kudos to [Slimedragon](https://near.org/near/widget/ProfilePage?accountId=slimedragon.near) for releasing it! Learn more about the indexers concept and other available solutions in [NEAR Docs](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/indexers)

17. **Deep dive with Illia:**
- Check this session with our Co-founder **Illia** as he explains NEAR's sharding and why it's the only viable path to scaling beyond what a single machine can provide. Click [here](https://twitter.com/ilblackdragon/status/1786745380035502119)

18. **Roketo's Open Source Initiative: Accelerating Streaming Development on NEAR:**

- Roketo, a key player in NEAR's streaming implementation, has transitioned to full open-source status after over 3 years of development. This move grants developers free access to the entire Roketo codebase, including web interfaces and smart contracts, fostering innovation and facilitating customizations for tailored streaming solutions. The initiative aims to propel the growth of streaming applications on NEAR while signaling Roketo's commitment to advancing programmable money in new directions. Discover more 👉[here](https://twitter.com/roketostream/status/1787870608052646354)

19.  **Developer Contributions Invitations:**
- Community members have been invited to contribute to dependencies cleanup and potential refactoring of NEAR crates. This initiative aims to enhance the efficiency and reliability of NEAR SDKs and tools. An example issue highlighting the need for cleanup and potential refactoring was shared 👉[here](https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/8888). Moreover, contributors are encouraged to explore the usage of Cargo deny for managing dependencies to ensure consistent and reliable builds. Support for reviews and merging of pull requests will be provided to facilitate the contributions process.

20. **Work Groups:**
- The protocol work group prepares to have its 10th work group meeting to discuss NEP-522, an important proposal addressing nonce behavior within the Near Protocol. NEP-522 aims to streamline transaction nonce management, offering a more efficient and user-friendly approach for developers. Developers are invited to join the discussion. Click 👉[here](https://github.com/near/NEPs/pull/522).


  
### THIS WEEKS TIPS 💡

`Tip`: For key management in NEAR development, it's suggested to focus efforts on improving `cli-rs` instead of `cli-js`.

`Tip`: When calling a contract using `near-api-js`, it's generally preferred to set up the account object (account.functionCall()) instead of the contract object (contract.method_name()), as the former is less confusing for developers.

`Tip`: To ensure consistent and reproducible builds across computers, developers can use "cargo near build" which aims to link compiled wasm contracts with their code, enabling consistent builds.
